query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
1 O poca nostra nobiltà di sangue, 2 se glorïar di te la gente fai 3 qua giù dove l’affetto nostro langue,
4 mirabil cosa non mi sarà mai: 5 ché là dove appetito non si torce, 6 dico nel cielo, io me ne gloriai.
query.result:
**English:**
1 Oh, our nobility of blood, how little, 2 if people glorify you down here 3 where our affections languish,
4 will never be a wondrous thing to me: 5 for there where desire is not distorted, 6 I mean in Heaven, I gloried in it.
**Old English:**
1 Ea, ure lytle æðelborennes, 2 gif ðu ðe selfne herige mid mannum 3 her niðer ðær ure lufu langað,
4 wundorlic ðing ne bið me næfre: 5 forðæm ðær ðær wilnung ne bið awended, 6 ic secge on heofonum, ic me ðæs gefeonde.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
7 Ben se’ tu manto che tosto raccorce: 8 sì che, se non s’appon di dì in die, 9 lo tempo va dintorno con le force.
query.result:
**English:**
7 You are well aware that time quickly shortens, 8 so that, if you do not add day to day, 9 time goes around with its forces.
**Old English:**
7 Þu eart wel gemyndig ðæt ðeos tid hrædlice gebrinco: 8 swa ðæt, gif ðu ðe ne geornæst dæghwamlice, 9 se tima gæð ymbutan mid his mihtum.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
19 Per tanti rivi s’empie d’allegrezza 20 la mente mia, che di sé fa letizia 21 perché può sostener che non si spezza.
query.result:
**English:**
19 Through so many streams is my mind filled with joy, 20 that it makes gladness of itself, 21 because it can endure without breaking.
**Old English:**
19 Þurh ða miclan flodas is min mod afylled 20 mid gefean, ðæt he ðæs fægnian mæg 21 ðæt he ðone bryne abidan mæg.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
28 Come s’avviva a lo spirar d’i venti 29 carbone in fiamma, così vid’ io quella 30 luce risplendere a’ miei blandimenti;
31 e come a li occhi miei si fé più bella, 32 così con voce più dolce e soave, 33 ma non con questa moderna favella,
34 dissemi: «Da quel dì che fu detto ‘Ave’ 35 al parto in che mia madre, ch’è or santa, 36 s’allevïò di me ond’ era grave,
37 al suo Leon cinquecento cinquanta 38 e trenta fiate venne questo foco 39 a rinfiammarsi sotto la sua pianta.
query.result:
**English:**
28 As a coal is quickened to flame by the breath of the winds, 29 so saw I that light glow at my entreaties;
30 and as it became fairer to my eyes, 31 so with a voice more sweet and gentle, 32 but not with this modern speech,
33 it said to me: "Since the day that 'Ave' was said 34 to the birth in which my mother, who is now holy, 35 was relieved of me with whom she was heavy,
36 to its Lion five hundred and fifty 37 and thirty times this fire has come 38 to rekindle itself beneath its paw.
**Old English:**
28 Swa swa ðone gled mon mæg oncweċċan 29 ðurh ðæs windes blæst, swa ic ða leohte geseah 30 ðurh mine bene lixan bliðe;
31 and swa swa heo fægerre wæs minum gesyhðe, 32 swa heo ðy wynsumre and ðy swettre spræc, 33 ac na ðurh ðas andweardan spræce,
34 cwæð to me: "Syððan ðam dæge ðe ðæt 'Ave' wæs 35 gecweden to ðam cilde ðe min moder, seo is nu halig, 36 me on woruld gebrohte, ðe heo ða swære wæs,
37 to his Leone fif hund wintra 38 and ðritig ðis fyr com 39 ðæt hit hine eft ontende under his fotum.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
40 Li antichi miei e io nacqui nel loco 41 dove si truova pria l’ultimo sesto 42 da quei che corre il vostro annüal gioco.
query.result:
**English:**
40 My ancestors and I were born in the place 41 where the last sixth is found first 42 by those who run your annual race.
**Old English:**
40 Mine yldran and ic wæron acendede on ðæm stede 41 ðær ðæt ytemeste sixte is ærest funden 42 fram ðæm ðe rynnað eower gearlice plegan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
43 Basti d’i miei maggiori udirne questo: 44 chi ei si fosser e onde venner quivi, 45 più è tacer che ragionare onesto.
query.result:
**English:**
43 Let it suffice for you to hear this about my ancestors: 44 who they were and how they came here, 45 it is more honorable to be silent than to speak.
**Old English:**
43 Genoh is ðæt ðe ðu gehyre ðisne hleopor: 44 hwa ða wæron and hwanan ða comon, 45 ðæt is betere ðæt ðu ðæt forbuge ðonne ðu ðæt reccan wille.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
46 Tutti color ch’a quel tempo eran ivi 47 da poter arme tra Marte e ’l Batista, 48 eran il quinto di quei ch’or son vivi.
query.result:
**English:**
46 All those who were there at that time, 47 able to bear arms between March and June, 48 were a fifth of those who are alive now.
**Old English:**
46 Ealle ða ðe ða wæron on ðam gefeohte 47 ðe wæpna mihton hebban betwux Martius and Iunius, 48 wæron ða fifta dæl ðara ðe nu synd on life.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
49 Ma la cittadinanza, ch’è or mista 50 di Campi, di Certaldo e di Fegghine, 51 pura vediesi ne l’ultimo artista.
query.result:
**English:**
49 But the citizenry, which is now mixed 50 with people from Campi, Certaldo, and Fegghine, 51 you could see purely in the last artist.
**Old English:**
49 Ac ða burhwaru, ðe nu is mencged 50 of Campum, of Certalde and of Fegghinum, 51 ðu mihtest on ðam æftemestan wyrhtan clæne geseon.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
52 Oh quanto fora meglio esser vicine 53 quelle genti ch’io dico, e al Galluzzo 54 e a Trespiano aver vostro confine,
55 che averle dentro e sostener lo puzzo 56 del villan d’Aguglion, di quel da Signa, 57 che già per barattare ha l’occhio aguzzo!
58 Se la gente ch’al mondo più traligna 59 non fosse stata a Cesare noverca, 60 ma come madre a suo figlio benigna,
61 tal fatto è fiorentino e cambia e merca, 62 che si sarebbe vòlto a Simifonti, 63 là dove andava l’avolo a la cerca;
64 sariesi Montemurlo ancor de’ Conti; 65 sarieno i Cerchi nel piovier d’Acone, 66 e forse in Valdigrieve i Buondelmonti.
query.result:
**English:**
52 Oh, how much better it would be to be neighbors 53 with those people I mentioned, and to have your borders 54 at Galluzzo and Trespiano,
55 than to have them inside and endure the stench 56 of the peasant from Aguglione, and the one from Signa, 57 who is already sharp-eyed for bartering!
58 If the people who are the most degenerate in the world 59 had not been a stepmother to Caesar, 60 but rather a kind mother to her son,
61 then the Florentine who now engages in trade and commerce 62 would have turned to begging at Simifonti, 63 where his grandfather used to go begging;
64 Montemurlo would still belong to the Conti family; 65 the Cerchi family would be in the parish of Acone; 66 and perhaps the Buondelmonti family would be in Valdigrieve.
**Old English:**
52 Eala, hu micle betere wære bion ða leoda ðe ic secge, and æt Galluzzo 53 and æt Trespiano hæbben eowre gemæro,
54 ðonne hæbben hie binnan and ðolian ðone stenc 55 ðæs ceorles of Aguglione, ðæs of Signa, 57 ðe nu for ceapunge hæfð ðone eage scearpne!
58 Gif ða leoda ðe on worulde mæst awyriað 59 næren wæron to Cesari stiopmodor, 60 ac swa swa modor to hire suna milde,
61 ðonne wære geworden Florentinus and ceapað and tiliað, 62 ðæt he wolde bion gewend to Simifonti, 63 ðær his ealda fæder eode ælmes biddan;
64 wære ðonne Montemurlo gyt ðara Conte; 65 wæren ða Cerchi on ðam piofor Acone; 66 and eac on Valdigrieve ða Buondelmonti.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
73 Se tu riguardi Luni e Orbisaglia 74 come sono ite, e come se ne vanno 75 di retro ad esse Chiusi e Sinigaglia,
76 udir come le schiatte si disfanno 77 non ti parrà nova cosa né forte, 78 poscia che le cittadi termine hanno.
query.result:
**English:**
73 If you look at Luni and Urbisaglia, 74 how they are gone, and how Chiusi and Sinigaglia 75 are going after them,
76 you will hear how the races of men are undone. 77 It will not seem new or strange to you, 78 since cities have their limits.
**Old English:**
73 Gif ðu Luni and Orbisaglia 74 behealdeð hu hi wæron, and hu hi forð gewendon, 75 and æfter him Chiusi and Sinigaglia,
76 ðu miht gehyran hu ða mægða forwurdon. 77 Ne ðinceð ðe ðæt wundorlic ne uncuð, 78 siððan ða burga ende habbað.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
79 Le vostre cose tutte hanno lor morte, 80 sì come voi; ma celasi in alcuna 81 che dura molto, e le vite son corte.
query.result:
**English:**
79 All your things have their death, 80 just like you; but it is hidden in some things 81 that last a long time, and lives are short.
**Old English:**
79 Ealle ðine ðing habbað heora deað, 80 swa swa ðu; ac hit is gehŷded on sumum 81 ðe lange dreogað, and ða lif syndon sceorte.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
82 E come ’l volger del ciel de la luna 83 cuopre e discuopre i liti sanza posa, 84 così fa di Fiorenza la Fortuna:
85 per che non dee parer mirabil cosa 86 ciò ch’io dirò de li alti Fiorentini 87 onde è la fama nel tempo nascosa.
query.result:
**English:**
82 And just as the turning of the heavens and the moon 83 covers and uncovers the shores without pause, 84 so does Fortune do to Florence:
85 therefore it should not seem a wondrous thing 86 what I will say about the lofty Florentines 87 whose fame is hidden in time.
**Old English:**
82 And swa swa ðæs heofones hweorfan and ðære monan 83 bewrið and unwríð ða lyde butan reste, 84 swa dǽð Fortúna of Florentia:
85 forðæm ne sceal ðyncan wundorlic ðing 86 ðæt ic secge be ðæm héan Florentínum 87 ðæra is ða mǽrðe on ðære tíde gehýded.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
94 Sovra la porta ch’al presente è carca 95 di nova fellonia di tanto peso 96 che tosto fia iattura de la barca,
97 erano i Ravignani, ond’ è disceso 98 il conte Guido e qualunque del nome 99 de l’alto Bellincione ha poscia preso.
query.result:
**English:**
94 Above the gate that is now burdened 95 with such a weight of new felony 96 that soon it will be the undoing of the boat,
97 were the Ravignani, from whom descended 98 Count Guido and all those who have since taken 99 the name of the noble Bellincione.
**Old English:**
94 Ufan ðære geate ðe nu is gehefegad 95 mid niwan felanysse ðæs miclan gewihtes 96 ðæt hraðe bið iattura ðære bâte,
97 wæron ða Rafenware, ðanon is cumen 98 se eorl Guido and æghwilc ðara ðe siððan 99 ðæs hean Bellincones naman hæfð genumen.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
100 Quel de la Pressa sapeva già come 101 regger si vuole, e avea Galigaio 102 dorata in casa sua già l’elsa e ’l pome.
query.result:
**English:**
100 He of La Pressa already knew how 101 one must rule, and Galigaio 102 already had the hilt and pommel gilded in his house.
**Old English:**
100 Se ðe of ðære Pressan wiste ða georne 101 hu man sceolde ricsian, and hæfde Galigaio 102 on his huse ða gyldene æx and ðone pom.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
103 Grand’ era già la colonna del Vaio, 104 Sacchetti, Giuochi, Fifanti e Barucci 105 e Galli e quei ch’arrossan per lo staio.
query.result:
**English:**
103 The column of the Vajo was already tall, 104 Sacchetti, Giuochi, Fifanti, and Barucci, 105 and Galli and those who blush for the bushel.
**Old English:**
103 Heh wæs seo Vaio columne heah, 104 Sacchetti, Giuochi, Fifanti, and Barucci, 105 and Galli and ða ðe for ðam staiele bleohð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
106 Lo ceppo di che nacquero i Calfucci 107 era già grande, e già eran tratti 108 a le curule Sizii e Arrigucci.
query.result:
**English:**
106 The stock from which the Calfucci sprang 107 was now great, and already had produced 108 Sizii and Arrigucci, who were drawn to the curule chairs.
**Old English:**
106 Se ceppe of ðæm ða Calfucci comon 107 wæs ða mycel, and ða wæron getealde 108 to ðæm curulscetan Sizii and Arrigucci.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
109 Oh quali io vidi quei che son disfatti 110 per lor superbia! e le palle de l’oro 111 fiorian Fiorenza in tutt’ i suoi gran fatti.
query.result:
**English:**
109 Oh, how many I saw there who were undone 110 through their pride! And the balls of gold 111 made Florence flourish in all her great deeds.
**Old English:**
109 Eala, hu manega ic ðær geseah ðara ðe forwurdon 110 ðurh heora ofermetto! and ða goldhorda 111 bleowdon Florentinan on eallum heora miclum weorcum.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
112 Così facieno i padri di coloro 113 che, sempre che la vostra chiesa vaca, 114 si fanno grassi stando a consistoro.
query.result:
**English:**
112 Thus did the fathers of those 113 who, whenever your church is vacant, 114 grow fat by staying in consistory.
**Old English:**
112 Swa dydon ða fæderas ðæra 113 ðe, swa oft swa eowre cyrice awesteð, 114 feormiað on ðam biscopstole.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
115 L’oltracotata schiatta che s’indraca 116 dietro a chi fugge, e a chi mostra ’l dente 117 o ver la borsa, com’ agnel si placa,
118 già venìa sù, ma di picciola gente; 119 sì che non piacque ad Ubertin Donato 120 che poï il suocero il fé lor parente.
query.result:
**English:**
115 The arrogant family that becomes enraged 116 against those who flee, and shows its teeth 117 or its purse, like a lamb is appeased,
118 was already rising, but with a small following; 119 so that it did not please Ubertino Donato 120 that his father-in-law made them his relatives.
**Old English:**
115 Se ofermodige mægð ðe ðe ondracað 116 æfter ðæm ðe flyð, and ðæm ðe ðone toð mæneð 117 oððe ofer ðone byrsean, swa ðæt lomb is gestilled,
118 com ða upp, ac mid lytlum mannum; 119 swa ðæt hit ne licode Ubertino Donato 120 ðæt his sweor ðone mæg ðurh hine geworhte.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
121 Già era ’l Caponsacco nel mercato 122 disceso giù da Fiesole, e già era 123 buon cittadino Giuda e Infangato.
query.result:
**English:**
121 Caponsacco was already in the marketplace, 122 having come down from Fiesole, and so was 123 the good citizen Giuda and Infangato.
**Old English:**
121 Wæs ða Caponsac on ðam ceapmange 122 ofstiged of Fiesole, and wæs ða 123 se goda burhware Giuda and Infangato.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
124 Io dirò cosa incredibile e vera: 125 nel picciol cerchio s’entrava per porta 126 che si nomava da quei de la Pera.
query.result:
**English:**
124 I will tell you something incredible but true: 125 one entered the small circle through a gate 126 that was named by those from La Pera.
**Old English:**
124 Ic secge ðe unaliefne ðing and soð: 125 ðurh ðone lytlan hring man eode in ða duru 126 ðe ða men of ðære Peran nemnedon.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
127 Ciascun che de la bella insegna porta 128 del gran barone il cui nome e ’l cui pregio 129 la festa di Tommaso riconforta,
130 da esso ebbe milizia e privilegio; 131 avvegna che con popol si rauni 132 oggi colui che la fascia col fregio.
query.result:
**English:**
127 Each one who bears the fair ensign 128 of the great baron whose name and whose worth 129 the feast of Thomas comforts,
130 from him had soldiery and privilege; 131 although he gathers with the people today 132 he who binds the sash with the ornament.
**Old English:**
127 Ælc ðara ðe ðære fægran tacne bær 128 ðæs mæran þegnes ðæs noma and ðæs lof 129 ðæs eadigan Thomas mæsse gefrefrode,
130 fram him hæfde here and heahgestreon; 131 ðeah ðe he mid folce gegaderod wære 132 to-dæg se ðe ðone fætels mid ðam frætewe bewunden hæfde.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
133 Già eran Gualterotti e Importuni; 134 e ancor saria Borgo più quïeto, 135 se di novi vicin fosser digiuni.
query.result:
**English:**
133 Already there were the Gualterotti and the Importuni; 134 and Borgo would still be quieter, 135 if it were empty of new neighbors.
**Old English:**
133 Þær wæron ða Gualterotti and ða Importuni; 134 and giet Borgo wære stilre, 135 gif hit wære digolra niwra gebuna.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
136 La casa di che nacque il vostro fleto, 137 per lo giusto disdegno che v’ha morti 138 e puose fine al vostro viver lieto,
139 era onorata, essa e suoi consorti: 140 o Buondelmonte, quanto mal fuggisti 141 le nozze süe per li altrui conforti!
142 Molti sarebber lieti, che son tristi, 143 se Dio t’avesse conceduto ad Ema 144 la prima volta ch’a città venisti.
query.result:
**English:**
136 The house from which your weeping was born, 137 through the just disdain that has killed you 138 and put an end to your happy life,
139 was honored, it and its people: 140 O Buondelmonte, how badly you fled 141 his marriage at the urging of others!
142 Many would be joyful, who are sad, 143 if God had granted you to Emma 144 the first time you came to the city.
**Old English:**
136 Þæt hus of ðæm ðin wóp wearð geboren, 137 ðurh ðone rihtwisan yfelwillan ðe eow hæfð ofslægen 138 and ðinum blissigan life ende geworht,
139 wæs gewuldrod, hit and his geferan: 140 Ea, Buondelmonte, hu yfle ðu ðine 141 gifta forðfluge ðurh ðara oðerra ræd!
142 Manega wæron bliðe, ðe nu sind sarige, 143 gif God ðe hæfde gegynned to Emman 144 ða ðu ærest to ðære byrig come.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
145 Ma conveniesi a quella pietra scema 146 che guarda ’l ponte, che Fiorenza fesse 147 vittima ne la sua pace postrema.
query.result:
**English:**
145 But you must go to that truncated stone 146 that guards the bridge, which Florence made 147 a victim in its final peace.
**Old English:**
145 Ac ðu scealt to ðæm sceamestan 146 ðe ðone brycg bewerið, ðe Florentia worhte 147 lac on hire æftemestan sibbe.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
148 Con queste genti, e con altre con esse, 149 vid’ io Fiorenza in sì fatto riposo, 150 che non avea cagione onde piangesse.
query.result:
**English:**
148 With these people, and with others with them, 149 I saw Florence in such a state of peace, 150 that it had no reason to weep.
**Old English:**
148 Mid ðyssum folce and oðrum mid him, 149 ic geseah Florentia on ðam sibbe, 150 ðæt heo næfde nane sorge hwy heo wepan sceolde.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
151 Con queste genti vid’io glorïoso 152 e giusto il popol suo, tanto che ’l giglio 153 non era ad asta mai posto a ritroso,
154 né per divisïon fatto vermiglio».
query.result:
**English:**
151 With these people I saw glorious 152 and just his people, so much so that the lily 153 was never placed upside down on a staff,
154 nor made red by division.
**Old English:**
151 Mid ðyssum folce ic geseah ðone arwurðan 152 and ðone rihtwisan his folces werod, swa ðæt ðæt lilie 153 næfre nære on stæfne æfre asett æfter bæce,
154 ne ðurh todælednysse geworht read.
